Projects.stack: GCP, React, Express, Node, NoSQL, Python, Docker, NGINX
Projects.description:
The gym where I play Pickleball allows members to book sessions 1 week out to the minute. I was constantly forgetting to book the sessions when they got released and as a result would miss out on the opportunity to play. So I figured out the API endpoints that are used to create the reservations and made a cloud function that would run on a schedule to do it for me. To take it one step further I created a fullstack app that automated the creation of the schedules by pulling the next weeks data from the gym's API.  
	 - Reverse engineered a popular gym's API to automate booking pickleball sessions using a GCP Cloud Function and GCP Cloud Scheduler to run scheduled jobs. 
	 - Designed web app to provide user friendly UI for dynamic creation of scheduled jobs. 
	 - Incorporated GCP SDK, Firebase Database and JWT Authentication into the backend to manage and protect GCP resources and multiple user's data

Projects.stack: Angular, Spring Boot, PostgreSQL, Java, Typescrip
Projects.description:
Java was the language I learned to code in but as soon as I learned Python I avoided using it outside of class work. Fast forward to working fulltime and I can't seem to escape Java so I wanted to make a web app from scratch to continue to grow my skills.  
	 - Developed a web app to rank coffee shops in New York. 
	 - Tracks user's favorite coffee sorted by different properties and allows the user to edit an delete their favorite coffee. 
	 - Used MongoDB to manage the database.

This is what you're on right now! It had been sometime since I used my React skills and I thought what better way than making something practical. For this project I really wanted the first half to focus only on frontend. For the second half I will be focusing on my photography which will require a backend to store the photos.
	 - Sharpened frontend skills with a focus on React and Typescript 
	 - Used Framer Motion to included animations and page transitions 
	 - Created complex CSS layouts

This was a final project for my HCI Capstone. I designed a VR proof of concept for a grad student's research centered around how VR could assist in geolocation. The idea was to come up with a cross between Google Earth VR and Google Maps street view. 
	 - Created VR experience using HTC Vive and Unity 
	 - Implemented movement systems such as: teleportation, flying and seamless transition between overhead and street view 
	 - Developed VR compatible HUD with menus that pulled information from APIs

Projects.description:
Used the MERN stack to create a web app to track wakeboard tricks. Hosted on AWS using an EC2 instance but taken down because NYC doesn't have anywhere for me to wakeboard. 
	 - Displays user's tricks sorted by different properties and allows the user to edit and delete their tricks. 
	 - Learned about database management using middleware

As a part of my OS class I created a customizable shell. I went from hating having to use the command line to create a shell from scratch. I also went from hating to C to tolerating it because writing OS level code is pretty neat. 
	 -  Gained experience using many different Linux system calls 
	 - Supports functionality for job control, background & foreground jobs, pipes & I/O redirection and process groups.
Projects.projectDesc: Due to Virginia Tech's honor code I cannot provide the repo

Projects.description:
As much as I hated my OS class there are 3 projects listed on this website from it because in hindsight I learned a lot of good stuff. This project was a memory allocator 
	 - Created a 64-bit Dynamic Storage Allocator that mimics the malloc, free and realloc routines
	 - Enhanced to handle various edge cases such as multiple threads and heap consistency.
	 -  Optimized space utilization and throughput by testing various designs.
Projects.projectDesc: Due to Virginia Tech's honor code I cannot provide the repo

Projects.description: Created a threadpool manager that handled allocating work to workers and would take in a user defined threadfunction. I learned way too much about PThreads from this project and have a deep appreciation for what goes on to make higher level multithreading possible. I include this project only to highlight that I am much much more knowledgeable on multithreading now but this is what started my interest. I ended up taking a graduate level parallel computing class that taught me everything from more on Pthreads to OpenMP and MPI. As a professional I have been able to give a presentation at a company wide tech conference for Capital One on multithreading within python.

Created an API to provide information about Virginia Tech sports and Blacksburg.

	 - Learned how to use the FastAPI framework
